awd_titl_txt: Northeast Washington Geospatial Technician Education Project
awd_abstract_narration:
Rural Washington has a strong demand for environmental and natural resource technicians with knowledge and skills in geospatial tools, data, and analysis.  However, rural schools have challenges in meeting performance benchmarks in STEM disciplines needed for geospatial careers, including technical careers in environmental and natural resources. The reasons for lower rural school STEM outcomes are complex. Cited factors for lower rural school performance in preparing students for STEM career pathways include a fewer number of experienced STEM teachers, fewer resources, and geographic isolation. This project explores the opportunity to better leverage community college resources to overcome barriers of geographic isolation.  Specifically, the project aims to expand the number of rural high school teachers with training in geospatial applications that are relevant to the region.  In addition, it aims to increase dual-credit (high-school and college) geospatial courses offered in rural communities. 

This project will deliver geospatial professional development training to twelve high school teachers from four isolated rural school districts, with the potential to involve two additional districts. Three instructors from Spokane Community College who teach college-level courses in rural northeast Washington communities will join high school teachers as learners receiving professional development training, with the intent to expand the college's capacity to teach dual-credit courses on geospatial topics directly in rural communities. Over the course of the project, the PI and Co-PIs will deliver two 3-day workshops at one of five Spokane Community College rural (satellite) campus facilities. The participating high school teachers and rural college instructors will also receive additional resources to support independent exploration of geospatial tools, data, and applications for integration into their classroom teaching. These additional resources include the creation of locally relevant standards-mapped GIS learning activities for high school classrooms. Rural communities and industries can benefit from an expanded number of students who pursue STEM career pathways that prepare them for meaningful local job opportunities and support local workforce needs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
NWGETEP: Bringing geospatial learning to rural schools

The Northeast Washington Geospatial Environmental Technician Education Project (NWGETEP) brings geospatial learning from Spokane Community College to rural high schools in our service district. We provide training to high school teachers, develop regionally-relevant geospatial activities for classrooms, support career awareness, and advance career pathways from rural high schools into degree programs at SCC.

During three years of funding, we trained 14 teachers from nine schools in our geospatial workshops and hosted 611 students at our annual career awareness event. We provided one-on-one mentoring to these teachers and developed 10 locally-tailored geospatial classroom activities. During 2020 alone, 262 rural high school students from mentored classrooms participated in geospatial learning activities. Based on self-assessment, high school teachers who participated in our workshops and students who engaged in geospatial learning reported increased skill and familiarity with geospatial concepts and their application.

We began establishing pathways from rural high schools into our Environmental Sciences programs through dual credit coursework. SCC's Introduction to Geographic Information Systems (GIS) course was offered through Washington State's Running Start program as embedded dual credit in a pilot run at one small district. We moved forward with a special online section of Introduction to GIS for rural high school students through Running Start and further established dual-credit opportunities within high school classrooms through Washington State's CTE Dual Credit program.

Although our project is not designed to examine avenues to teacher engagement, several of our experiences may help formulate testable hypotheses related to teacher participation learning novel technology. Within our cohort, schools with smaller class sizes, and newer teachers were more apt to use geospatial tools. This may rise from a teacher's openness to assimilate new technologies while building curriculum from the ground up. It may also reflect new teachers' relative comfort with app-based spatial tools like Google Maps. Small class sizes and the flexible teaching they allow for may be the reason that smaller schools more often used geospatial technologies.

More teachers incorporated geospatial activities into classroom learning during 2020/2021 than 2019/2020. When learning moved online due to the pandemic, teachers adapted existing curriculum and adopted new activities. This opened a window for geospatial activities that enhanced and supported each teacher's content area. Mentoring and tailored activities provided by NWGETEP were essential for making this step into new technology.

Teachers need the opportunity to explore their content area through geospatial technologies and these technologies should be presented as such a tool from their first introduction. When geospatial learning is seen as a technology used for the sake of learning about technology -  we miss an opportunity. Just as "keyboarding" classes from the 1980's became irrelevant in a world saturated with computers, stand-alone geospatial lessons don't make sense where spatial data and its uses surround us daily. During 2020, as teachers searched for new ways to explore and deliver content online, maps and geospatial exploration became relevant and convenient.

 While NWGETEP continues to function beyond the NSF-funded period, our experiences with the project have shaped interest in increasing the accessibility of applied post-secondary environmental science education in rural areas. Moving forward, our intent is to develop additional pathways from rural high schools into SCC programs, to optimize learning modalities for delivery of hands-on skills to rural students, and to negotiate efficient transfer agreements from our technical programs into regional universities.


Last Modified: 11/22/2021
Modified by: Marilyn Nielson

Image
  • Students participate in a geographic information systems (GIS) activity during our 2019 event.
    Janelle Earle
    Copyrighted
    Marilyn Nielson
    Geospatial Environmental Sciences Career Day
